messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Norisuke / Ron H.
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, If you find any close matches in the book, or there is a similar kinko example- send me an image. I ll decide whether to track down and buy the book. This
messages.messageBody:
Ron,

If you find any close matches in the book, or there is
a similar kinko example- send me an image. I'll decide
whether to track down and buy the book. This suba not
being signed, I doubt few other than a very confident
judge would give it *definitely* to Norisuke. But I
hope you find a dead ringer of a match for me.

A good number of people have told me they are skipping
San Fran this year for a variety of reasons. I am too,
due to business.

If you make it to Tampa in 2007, feel free to drive
down and fish off our dock. Snook is tasty. Right up
their with nice scottish rainbow trout.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Norisuke / Ron H.
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Curran - Sorry for the delay in responding but things have been busy around here -- no, not sword busy, unfortunately! I ve yet to look through that book
messages.messageBody:
Hi Curran -

Sorry for the delay in responding but things have been busy around here -- no, not "sword" busy, unfortunately! I've yet to look through that book for your tsuba but will make a point to do so tomorrow (or later tonight).

I'm not "married" this book but I've just recently purchased a Namban book (Japanese) so honestly, I don't need another. My book came from a Japanese dealer but I can look and see what I paid for it and let you know, in case you're interested. I'll check and let you know, okay?

Skipping SF this August -- (sigh) -- since I'm going to Japan in October. It will feel good to stay home for 2-1/2 months after a short (fishing) trip south of St. Louis next week. Will be in touch...

Ron

----- Original Message -----
From: Curran Campbell
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 11, 2006 10:49 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Norisuke / Ron H.


Ron,

I was not aware there was a Norisuke book. Want to
consider trading for the Namban tsuba book?

Seriously, if you find anything similar, please send
me a copy of the picture.

Curran

--- Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:

> Curran -
>
> Finally got around to looking at your tsuba's photo
> and I can see why -- the flowers -- you think
> Norisuke. I have a book entirely on Norisuke which
> I'll take a look at, soon. I'm in the middle of
> photographing stuff in prep for our stein club
> meeting which I'm hosting this weekend. )Yes, too
> many "interests!") Anyway, I'll have a look in the
> book. No english but photos are pretty good. Once
> owned a mumei tsuba which was probably Norisuke
> work; Alan Harvie ended up with it.
>
> Ron
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Curran Campbell

> Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke
>
>
> Alan,
>
> The tsuba is very thick and rich shakudo. It is
> very
> heavy. The gold wire used is also very heavy
> guage,
> set extremely deep into channels. It has retained
> about 99.9% of the inlay, but there is a small
> spot on
> the mimi where I can see how deep the channels run
> and
> the gold wire extends all the way into it.
>
> According to Haynes and one or two other sources,
> the
> Norisuke line did work in Kinko sometimes.
>
> I am not saying with 100% certainty that this is a
> Norisuke, but there is a similar tsuba out there
> by
> Norisuke and the more that I look at other tsuba
> by
> the Norisuke family, the more I see the same
> design
> elements over and over again. Leaf shape. Flower
> petal
> engraving. Flower engraving. General composition.
> Very
> much like a painting, the great number of details
> evident in a soft metal heavily carved piece like
> this
> seem to me a signature. There is some variation,
> like
> there is a very similar 1st gen Norisuke example
> with
> near identical leaves, but the main vein of the
> leaf
> is done in a single track of gold vs the double
> vein I
> have on this leaf.
> I like to figure things out before I submit them
> to
> shinsa, and sometimes if I am happy enough with an
> answer and intend to keep a piece- I don't submit
> to
> shinsa. I'd be surprised if I actually got a
> 'Norisuke' call on this, but as a
> newbie-intermediate
> having something like this seem to click into
> place
> has been very satisfying. Yet I may be absolutely
> wrong! So if I can stand on someone's shoulder and
> see
> further into this.... I welcome the view.
>
> If you want to take a crack at the other tsuba
> that
> has been a challenge for me, I will dig that photo
> out
> too and post it. This 'Norisuke' has been the more
> interesting piece and horribly difficult to
> photograph
> given the highly reflective shakudo and gold.
> Photography is not a strong skill for me, yet the
> devil of a good identification is also in the
> detail
> of the other one.
>
> Curran
>

cutting and pasting from other people's books, and so it was much easier.
Perhaps a bit tortured.

Gordon

Gordon,

Funny you should mention that. I was wondering
yesterday who interpreted a Wakayama passage as, "This
makes me feel just a little bit maudlin." (Iwata
Norisuke section, 3rd paragraph).

I could only imagine what the original Japanese must
have been. I figured some interpretor had been
tortured a bit to try and hit the original tone of
Wakayama.

Curran

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke
messages.msgSnippet: Yeah, I just did another one of his, but he wrote it himself instead and cutting and pasting from other people s books, and  so it was much easier. Perhaps a
messages.messageBody:
Yeah, I just did another one of his, but he wrote it himself instead and
cutting and pasting from other people's books, and so it was much easier.
Perhaps a bit tortured.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Curran Campbell
Sent: Wednesday, July 12, 2006 12:58 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke



Gordon,

Funny you should mention that. I was wondering
yesterday who interpreted a Wakayama passage as, "This
makes me feel just a little bit maudlin." (Iwata
Norisuke section, 3rd paragraph).

I could only imagine what the original Japanese must
have been. I figured some interpretor had been
tortured a bit to try and hit the original tone of
Wakayama.

Curran

>

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Norisuke / Ron H.
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, I was not aware there was a Norisuke book. Want to consider trading for the Namban tsuba book? Seriously, if you find anything similar, please send me a
messages.messageBody:
Ron,

I was not aware there was a Norisuke book. Want to
consider trading for the Namban tsuba book?

Seriously, if you find anything similar, please send
me a copy of the picture.

Curran


--- Ron Hartmann <swords@...> wrote:

> Curran -
>
> Finally got around to looking at your tsuba's photo
> and I can see why -- the flowers -- you think
> Norisuke. I have a book entirely on Norisuke which
> I'll take a look at, soon. I'm in the middle of
> photographing stuff in prep for our stein club
> meeting which I'm hosting this weekend. )Yes, too
> many "interests!") Anyway, I'll have a look in the
> book. No english but photos are pretty good. Once
> owned a mumei tsuba which was probably Norisuke
> work; Alan Harvie ended up with it.
>
> Ron
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Curran Campbell
> To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
> Sent: Tuesday, July 11, 2006 10:58 AM
> Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari
> Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke
>
>
> Alan,
>
> The tsuba is very thick and rich shakudo. It is

messages.messageBody:
Thanks. Those translations were my introduction to Norisuke and Wakayama
sensei's terrible prose.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Curran Campbell
Sent: Tuesday, July 11, 2006 1:54 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke



Gordon,

Yes there is great stuff in them. I think they are one
of the best buys for newbies at roughtly $20 each. I'd
put it right up there with Nagayama as some of the
first books anyone starting to studying Nihonto should
own. I even have 2 copies of some Volumes, since my
desk copies tend to get a bit roughed up.

I was about to pull the Vol 3 off the shelf to review
the Owari-Origin-of-Akasaka Tsuba article, in regards
to an "Owari-esque" Akasaka tsuba that just arrived
today. It had not occurred to me to look in there for
possible Norisuke information.

Curran

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke
messages.msgSnippet: Curran - Finally got around to looking at your tsuba s photo and I can see why -- the flowers -- you think Norisuke. I have a book entirely on Norisuke which
messages.messageBody:
Curran -

Finally got around to looking at your tsuba's photo and I can see why -- the flowers -- you think Norisuke. I have a book entirely on Norisuke which I'll take a look at, soon. I'm in the middle of photographing stuff in prep for our stein club meeting which I'm hosting this weekend. )Yes, too many "interests!") Anyway, I'll have a look in the book. No english but photos are pretty good. Once owned a mumei tsuba which was probably Norisuke work; Alan Harvie ended up with it.

Ron
----- Original Message -----
From: Curran Campbell
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 11, 2006 10:58 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke


Alan,

The tsuba is very thick and rich shakudo. It is very
heavy. The gold wire used is also very heavy guage,
set extremely deep into channels. It has retained
about 99.9% of the inlay, but there is a small spot on
the mimi where I can see how deep the channels run and
the gold wire extends all the way into it.

According to Haynes and one or two other sources, the
Norisuke line did work in Kinko sometimes.

I am not saying with 100% certainty that this is a
Norisuke, but there is a similar tsuba out there by
Norisuke and the more that I look at other tsuba by
the Norisuke family, the more I see the same design
elements over and over again. Leaf shape. Flower petal
engraving. Flower engraving. General composition. Very
much like a painting, the great number of details
evident in a soft metal heavily carved piece like this
seem to me a signature. There is some variation, like
there is a very similar 1st gen Norisuke example with
near identical leaves, but the main vein of the leaf
is done in a single track of gold vs the double vein I
have on this leaf.
I like to figure things out before I submit them to
shinsa, and sometimes if I am happy enough with an
answer and intend to keep a piece- I don't submit to
shinsa. I'd be surprised if I actually got a
'Norisuke' call on this, but as a newbie-intermediate
having something like this seem to click into place
has been very satisfying. Yet I may be absolutely
wrong! So if I can stand on someone's shoulder and see
further into this.... I welcome the view.

If you want to take a crack at the other tsuba that
has been a challenge for me, I will dig that photo out
too and post it. This 'Norisuke' has been the more
interesting piece and horribly difficult to photograph
given the highly reflective shakudo and gold.
Photography is not a strong skill for me, yet the
devil of a good identification is also in the detail
of the other one.

Curran

--- Alan Bale <abale@...> wrote:

> Is the tsuba iron or shakudo? I don't recall ever
> seeing a soft metal tsuba by Norisuke.
> Alan

Is the tsuba iron or shakudo? I don't recall ever seeing a soft metal tsuba by Norisuke.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: Curran Campbell
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, July 10, 2006 6:37 AM
Subject: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke


List,

Regarding this tsuba: (Mystery Tsuba in Curran Folder)

http://tinyurl.com/lc3j2

Following up on the helpful lead provided by Alan
Bale, I was able to borrow a copy of "Owari to Mikawa
no Tanko" aka. Big Blue Owari Den tsuba book.

Reading through it as much as possible and consulting
other texts, I feel the tsuba is an unsigned Owari
kinko tsuba by Norisuke or someone close.

Anyone familiar with the Norisuke kinko work able to
comment? Anyone able to tell me more about Norisuke
kinko work?

I'd appreciate any insight or feedback.

Curran

messages.messageBody:
Gordon,

Yes there is great stuff in them. I think they are one
of the best buys for newbies at roughtly $20 each. I'd
put it right up there with Nagayama as some of the
first books anyone starting to studying Nihonto should
own. I even have 2 copies of some Volumes, since my
desk copies tend to get a bit roughed up.

I was about to pull the Vol 3 off the shelf to review
the Owari-Origin-of-Akasaka Tsuba article, in regards
to an "Owari-esque" Akasaka tsuba that just arrived
today. It had not occurred to me to look in there for
possible Norisuke information.

Curran

messages.messageBody:
Nobody remembers these old Art and the Swords, but there is some good work
in there, if I may say so.



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com] On
Behalf Of Curran Campbell
Sent: Tuesday, July 11, 2006 11:04 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke



Gents,

Thank you. That is perfect.
Right under my nose.

Some of the Norisuke examples shown in Art & the Sword
Vol 3 persuade me more that this is very close to
their work.

Any other sources for images of kinko Norisuke work?

Curran

messages.msgSnippet: Volume 3 1990 ... From: Gordon Robson To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com Sent: 07/10/2006 6:26 PM
messages.messageBody:
Volume 3 1990
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson<mailto:robsongo@...>
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: 07/10/2006 6:26 PM
Subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke


Have you looked at the Art and the Sword volume on Owari fittings? I don't
remember the volume, but it was in the late 90s or so.

Gordon

-----Original Message-----
From: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com> [mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>] On
Behalf Of Curran Campbell
Sent: Monday, July 10, 2006 2:38 PM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com<mailto:nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Subject: [nihontostudy] Followup on Owari Kinko Tsuba and Norisuke

List,

Regarding this tsuba: (Mystery Tsuba in Curran Folder)

http://tinyurl.<http://tinyurl./> <http://tinyurl.com/lc3j2<http://tinyurl.com/lc3j2>> com/lc3j2

Following up on the helpful lead provided by Alan
Bale, I was able to borrow a copy of "Owari to Mikawa
no Tanko" aka. Big Blue Owari Den tsuba book.

Reading through it as much as possible and consulting
other texts, I feel the tsuba is an unsigned Owari
kinko tsuba by Norisuke or someone close.

Anyone familiar with the Norisuke kinko work able to
comment? Anyone able to tell me more about Norisuke
kinko work?

I'd appreciate any insight or feedback.

Curran
